journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Theoretical and experimental study on the dynamic response of multi-disk rotor system with flexible coupling misalignment

article-meta.aff: State Key Laboratory of Mechanical System and Vibration, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, PR China

author-notes.corresp: Zhao Wan, State Key Laboratory of Mechanical System and Vibration, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, 200240, PR China. Email: epistemeray@gmail.com

abstract.p: The dynamic response of a multi-disk rotor system with coupling misalignment is investigated theoretically and experimentally, considering the nonlinear oil film force. The rotor is simplified to a lumped mass model and the governing equations are derived considering the gyroscopic effect. The reacting forces and moments caused by misalignment are treated as excitations to the rotor system. The unbalanced responses of the system with/without misalignment are calculated using a numerical integration method and comparisons made. Spectrum cascades are utilized to obtain the overall view of the response characteristics during the starting up of the rotor. The modified Bode plot is used to trend the amplitude variation of different frequency components. The study indicates that coupling misalignment can cause 2X, 3X, 4X, and other multiple frequency responses. The amplitude of the 2X vibration could be larger than that of the 1X one, depending on the misalignment level. Also, the amplitude of 2X vibration decreases with the increment of the distance between the measuring points and the coupling. Theoretical analysis also reveals that oil whip will happen when the rotating speed exceeds twice the first critical speed of the rotor system. It is suggested that coupling misalignment could suppress the vibration of the rotor and delay the occurrence of oil whip. The experimental and theoretical results agree well with each other, which verify the model adopted and analytical procedure in this study.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Misalignment is one of the most common problems of rotating machinery which can induce many other malfunctions; however, limited attentions have been paid to the problem compared to unbalance, crack, rub and impact, fluid-induced vibrations, etc. There are mainly two reasons for this situation. First, misalignment is comparatively easy to identify and adjust, and there are lots of equipments and methods for measurement and adjustment. Second, it is hard to create an accurate model to describe the effects of misalignment for different kinds of couplings which are strong structurally and very sensitive to the running conditions.

There are still a number of researchers who have made remarkable contributions to this subject. Gibbons1 first derived the reacting forces and moments caused by parallel coupling misalignment. Xu and Marangoni2,3 conducted theoretical and experimental studies on a rotor system subject to coupling misalignment and unbalance. They concluded that the forced vibration caused by misalignment contains multiple components of the rotating frequency. Sekhar and Prabhu4 developed a finite element method (FEM) model for a rotor–coupling–bearing system with misalignment and analyzed the unbalanced responses, which revealed that the location of the coupling with respect to the bending mode has a strong influence on the vibrations. Lee and Lee5 studied the modeling and vibration of a misaligned rotor–ball bearing system by treating the reaction loads and deformations on the bearing and coupling elements as the misalignment effect. Prabhakar et al.6,7 analyzed the transient response of a misaligned rotor–coupling–bearing system passing through the critical speed, and the continuous wavelet transformation was applied to extract the features of the system. Patel and Darpe7,8 made a remarkable experimental study on the misaligned rotor, and the characteristics of the misaligned rotor were analyzed using the time domain waveforms, orbits, and spectra. It is concluded that, besides misalignment, crack and stiffness asymmetry can also generate strong 2X harmonic vibrations. Sudhakar and Sekhar9 systematically summarized the works on the misalignment modeling and discussed the identification and monitoring methods. The effects of misalignment on the stability and the first critical speed of the rotor system are discussed particularly.

Literature review shows that the majority of studies on misalignment were theoretical, while the experimental investigations were relatively limited. In addition, the theoretical and experimental studies were usually obscured and not unified systemically. Moreover, most studies failed to provide a comprehensive view of the influences of misalignment on the amplitude and spectrum of the rotor system within a wide speed range during starting up, but only discussed the responses at several concerned speeds. The nonlinearity caused by oil lubricated journal bearing was not considered in those studies either.

In this study, the lumped mass model of the multi-disk rotor–bearing system is built with consideration on the nonlinear oil film force. A concise model for the coupling misalignment is employed. The dynamic responses of the rotor–bearing system with/without coupling misalignment are discussed and compared. The amplitude–speed response and spectrum cascade analysis are provided to get a full view of the characteristics of the rotor system during starting up. Experimental and theoretical studies show a good agreement with each other, which verifies the analytical procedure adopted in this study.

sec.title: Modeling of the rotor–bearing system with coupling misalignment
The lumped mass model of the rotor–bearing system
sec.p: The FEM model is widely used in rotor dynamics since Nelson10 first derived the dynamic equations of a rotor in the finite element form. Usually, for analysis accuracy, the rotor is discretized to beam elements with the size as small as possible which in turn makes the dimension of the governing equations extremely high. When the nonlinear forces are considered, the high-dimensional nonlinear problem is apt to be divergent or very hard to solve. In this study, the rotor system is simplified to a lumped mass model based on which governing equations with lower dimensions are derived.

Figure 1 is the simplified lumped mass model of the rotor system. The disks are connected with massless flexible shaft, and the masses of the shaft and disks are lumped to five distributed nodes. Figure 1.
Simplified model of the rotor system.

Take XOZ plane, for example, the forces and moments on the disk and mass-less shaft are demonstrated in Figure 2. For the disk, there are two degrees of freedom, the translational and angular, and the displacement vector of Disk-(i) is (1){Ux}i =[Xiθyi]T
Figure 2.
Forces and moments on the disk and shaft.
The dynamic equations of the disk are (2){miX··i=Fxi L-Fxi R-Foxi+mieiω2cos(ωt)Jdiθ··yi-ωJpiθ·xi=-Myi L+Myi R

Without considering the shearing effect, the relations between the forces and moments with the displacements of adjacent nodes are (3){Xi+1=Xi+li·θyi+li 22E·IiMyi R+li 36E·IiFxi Rθy,i+1=θyi+liE·IiMyi R+li 22E·IiFxi RMy,i+1 L=Myi R+l·Fxi RFx,i+1 L=Fxi R

The boundary conditions of the nodes on each ends of the rotor, i.e. the left bearing (node-1/Disk-1) and the right bearing (node-5/Disk-5), are (4){Fx1 L=Fx1,misalignMy1 L=My1,misalignFox1=Fbx1 , {Fx5 R=0My5 R=0Fox1=Fbx5 where Fx1,misalign and My1,misalign are the force and moment caused by coupling misalignment, respectively, and Fbx1 and Fbx5 the nonlinear oil film forces.

The dynamic equations in XOZ plane can finally be obtained by doing several substitutions and are given below. The motion equations in the YOZ plane can be obtained in the same way. (5){ m1X¨1=−k11(X1−X2)−k12(θy1+θy2)−Fbx1+Fx1,misalignJd1θ¨y1−ωJp1θ˙x1=−k12(X1−X2)−k13(2θy1+θy2)+My1,misalign { m2X¨2=(k11(X1−X2)+k12(θy1+θy2))−(k21(X2−X3)+k22(θy2+θy3))+Fex2Jd2θ¨y2−ωJp2θ˙x2=−(k12(X1−X2)+k13(θy1+2θy2))+(k22(−X2+X3)−k23(2θy2+θy3)) { m3X¨3=(k21(X2−X3)+k22(θy2+θy3))−(k31(X3−X4)+k32(θy3+θy4))+Fex3Jd3θ¨y3−ωJp3θ˙x3=−(k22(X2−X3)+k23(θy2+2θy3))+(k32(−X3+X4)−k33(2θy3+θy4)) { m4X¨4=(k31(X3−X4)+k32(θy3+θy4))−(k41(X4−X5)+k42(θy4+θy5))+Fex4Jd4θ¨y4−ωJp4θ˙x4=−(k32(X3−X4)+k33(θy3+2θy4))+(k42(−X4+X5)−k43(2θy4+θy5)) { m5X¨5=(k41(X4−X5)+k42(θy4+θy5))−Fbx5Jd5θ¨y5−ωJp5θ˙x5=−(k42(X4−X5)+k43(θy4+2θy5)) where ki1=12E·IiLi 3 , ki2=6E·IiLi 2 , ki3=2E·IiLi 2 , and i=1,2,3,4 .
The unbalanced forces are given as (6){FexiFeyi}={mieiωr 2cos(ωrt+ϕi)mieiωr 2sin(ωrt+ϕi)},i=2,3,4
The nonlinear oil film forces of short journal bearings can be expressed as11 (7){FbxiFbyi}=σ{fbxifbyi},i=1,5.

sec.title: Reacting forces and moments caused by coupling misalignment
sec.p: As already mentioned, it is hard to create an accurate model to depict the influence of misalignment on the rotor system. The lack of information about the forces and the bending moments generated in the coupling due to misalignment hinders a deeper understanding of the coupling influence on the system.

The reacting forces and moments introduced here are presented by Sekhar and Prabhu.4 This model builds the direct relationships between the forces and moments with the amounts of misalignment, which can be measured using the reverse indicator method.12 The reacting forces and moments in the two types of misalignments are listed as follows.

Parallel misalignment (8){ Mx1=Tqsin⁡(θ1)+Kbφ1My1=Tqsin⁡(φ1)−Kbθ1 ;{ Mx2=Tqsin⁡(θ2)−Kbφ2My2=Tqsin⁡(φ2)+Kbθ2 ;{ Mz1=TqMz2=−Tq { Fx1=−(My1+My2)/Z3Fy1=(Mx1+Mx2)/Z3 ;{ Fx2=−Fx1Fy2=−Fy1 ; { Fz1=KaΔZ+Ka(ΔZ)3Fz2=Fz1
Angular misalignment (9){Mx1=0My1=0 ; {Mx2=-Kbθ3My2=Tqsin(θ3) ; {Mz1=Tq/cos(θ3)Mz2=-Tq {Fx1=-(My1+My2)/Z3Fy1=(Mx1+Mx2)/Z3 ; {Fx2=-Fx1Fy2=-Fy1 ; {Fz1=(KaΔZ+Ka(ΔZ)3)/cos(θ3)Fz2=Fz1

It can be observed from equations (8) and (9) that the forces Fxi,Fyi,i=1,2 , and the bending moments Mxi,Myi,i=1,2, caused by misalignment are the functions of the angular displacements and lateral translational displacements of misalignment, and are closely related with the torque ( Tq ) the coupling transmitted and the bending spring rate ( Kb ) of the coupling. It is important to be aware that the angular displacements and lateral translational displacements of misalignment are measured when the rotor is static; therefore, Fxi,Fyi,i=1,2 and Mxi,Myi,i=1,2, are static preloads created by the coupling misalignment. When the rotor is spinning, the misaligned angular displacements and lateral translational displacements change with the vibration of the rotor, and the reacting forces and moments are no longer static but dynamic excitations which are also the functions of the vibration displacements. So, the model might be defective in its accuracy. Despite these, this model is significant and easy to understand as it manifested.
The misaligning force and moment are (12){Fx1,misalign=Qc 2(1)=Fx2(sin(ωt)+sin(2ωt)+sin(3ωt)+sin(4ωt))My1,misalign=Qc 2(3)=My2(sin(ωt)+sin(2ωt)+sin(3ωt)+sin(4ωt))

The parameters of the diaphragm coupling and misalignment are measured using reverse indicator method12 and listed in Table 1. Table 1.
Parameters of the diaphragm coupling and misalignment.
Item Value
Rated torque, Tq
35 N·m
Bending spring rate per degree per diskpack, Kb
65 N·m/deg/diskpack
Rotational spring stiffness, Ka
1.5e6 N/m/diskpack
Axial deflection of coupling, ΔZ
0.8 mm
center of articulation, Z3
99.3 mm
Angular misalignment, θ3
0.5°
Parallel misalignment θ1 = 0.2°, φ1 = −0.06°
θ2 = −0.14°, φ2 = −0.104°

sec.title: Theoretical study on the misaligned rotor-bearing system
sec.p:
The parameters of the multi-disk rotor-bearing system are listed in Table 2. Table 2.
Parameters of the rotor–bearing system.
Item Value
Mass (kg)
m1=2.4 , m2=18, m3=20.2 , m4=18 , and m5=2.2
Length (m)
L1=0.3 , L2=0.3325, L3=0.3325 , and L4=0.3
Diameter (mm)
D1=45 , D2=50 , D3=50 , and L4=45
Polar moment of inertia (10−3 kg·m2)
Jp1=0.5 , Jp2=105 , Jp3=60 , Jp4=105 , and Jp5=0.4
Transverse moment of inertia (10−3 kg·m2)
Jd1=0.25 , Jd2=55.6 , Jd3=46 , Jd4=55.6 , and Jd5=0.2
Bearing parameters
R=20 mm , L=32 mm , c=0.08 mm , and μ=0.042 Pa·s
Eccentricity ( g×mm )
e1=0 , e2=25×75 , e3=12.5×75 , e4=25×75 , and e5=0
Damping ratio (ζ)
ζ=0.035
Young’ modulus (E)
E=210e9 Pa

Table 3 presents the first three orders of natrual frequencies of free rotor and the constrained rotor calculated using the eigenvalue theory. To get the dynamic response of the system, the numerical integration is carried out using the step-adaptive four-order Runge–Kutta method. It is worth noting that when the angular displacements and the nonlinear oil film forces are considered, the system is very sensitive to integration error and apt to divergent numerically. The dimensionless initial values are recommended to be the small perturbations to the system, i.e. 1.0e−4. In this study, responses in 150 periods are calculated and only the steady responses of the last 50 periods are reserved for analysis. Table 3.
Natural frequencies of the rotor (without damping).
Order Free (Hz) Constrained (Hz)
1 0 31.66
2 91.16 119.50
3 205.36 236.75

Figure 3 shows the root mean square (RMS) amplitude–speed response of the left disk. Curve-1 with circles on it is the amplitude response considering coupling misalignment and Curve-2 the amplitude response without considering it. It can be observed from Curve-2 that the first critical speed of the rotor–bearing system is about 30 Hz, which approximates to the first-order natural frequency of the constrained rotor, as listed in Table 3. Also, when the rotating frequency exceeds 72 Hz, which is more than twice of the first critical speed, the amplitude increases quickly and the phenomenon is known as the oil whip. When compared with Curve-1, it can be found that misalignment does not change the first critical speed of the rotor system, but the speed when the system enters oil whip is higher than that of the condition without considering the misalignment. In addition, the amplitude of oil whip is smaller compared with the condition considering misalignment, which suggests that the coupling can suppress the vibration of the rotor system. Figure 3.
The RMS amplitude–speed response of the left disk.

Figure 4 is the spectrum cascade of the horizontal vibration of the left bearing. The annotations 1X, 2X and 3X represent one, two, and three times of the rotating frequency of the rotor, respectively. The 1 × 1st and 2 × 1st indicate one and two times of the first critical speed, respectively. It can be observed from Figure 4(a) that when the oil whip happens, the spectrum of the response has a sub-synchronous component, which approximates to the first natural frequency of the system. The frequency of the sub-synchronous component does not change as the rotating speed increases. The amplitude of the sub-synchronous vibration caused by oil whip is much higher than the vibration caused by unbalance. The system is in a condition of self-excited resonance caused by nonlinear oil film force.13 The theoretical study also suggests that besides the 1 × 1st vibration, there is also the 2 × 1st inner resonance when oil whip happens. Figure 4.
Spectra cascade of the horizontal vibrations of the left bearing: (a) without coupling misalignment and (b) with coupling misalignment.

Figure 4(b) shows the spectrum cascade of the horizontal vibration of the left bearing, where the forces and moments caused by the misalignment are applied to. The oil whip happens at 82 Hz, which is higher than the condition without considering misalignment. It is obvious that the response contains multiple frequency components (2X, 3X, and 4X), as the model of coupling misalignment indicated. The power of the vibrations induced by misalignment decreases as the order of the multiple frequency increases, e.g. the vibration amplitude of 3X component is lower than that of 2X one.

Figure 5 shows the spectrum cascade of the horizontal vibration of the left disk. The multiple frequency components exist but are not obvious. The powers of multiple frequency vibrations are comparatively smaller compared with those of the left bearing in Figure 4, which means that the influence of misalignment decreases as the distance between the concern nodes with the misaligned coupling increases. Also, as the speed increases, the 1X vibration caused by unbalance predominates over the multiple frequency vibrations caused by misalignment. Figure 5.
Spectra cascade of the horizontal vibrations of the left disk: (a) without coupling misalignment and (b) with coupling misalignment.

To be more specific, the waveforms, the spectra, and the orbits of the left bearing at four key rotating frequencies are selected and shown in Figures 6 to 8, respectively. It is quite clear that the vibration responses contain 1X, 2X, 3X, and 4X harmonic components. In addition, when oil whip happens, at 90 Hz, the sub-synchronous vibration also appears. It can be observed that the orbits of at 36 and 58 Hz are figure ‘8’ shaped, which are the superposition of the vibrations of different frequencies. Figure 6.
Waveforms of the horizontal vibrations of the left bearing.
Figure 7.
Spectra of the horizontal vibrations of the left bearing.
Figure 8.
Center orbits of the left bearing.

sec.title: Experimental study on misaligned rotor system
Test rig configuration
sec.p:
The configuration and snap shot of the test rig are shown in Figure 9. The test rig mainly consists of 10 parts: (1) the frequency-variable motor, controlled by an inverter; (2) the low-speed diaphragm coupling that is used to connect the motor and gearbox; (3) the speed-increasing gearbox, with the speed ratio of 1:4; (4) the high-speed diaphragm coupling that is used to connect the gearbox and the main shaft; (5) the left housing and left cylindrical journal bearing; (6) the left disk that is used for balancing; (7) the main shaft; (8) the middle disk; (9) the right disk; and (10) right housing and journal bearing. Figure 9.
Test rig: (a) configuration and (b) snap shot.

The diaphragm coupling is a kind of flexible coupling. It can tolerate or compensate the assembly misalignment (angular and parallel misalignments) to some extent, which depends on the structure of the coupling. The rated torque of the high-speed diaphragm coupling can transmit is 400 Nm, and the max value 900 Nm. The maximum speed of the rotor is 12,000 r/min. The rotor is supported with the oil lubricated cylindrical journal bearings at each end. Eddy current sensors are used to measure the displacements at the concerned positions, whose resolution is 1 µm/8 mV after signal amplification. Channel-1 and Channel-2 are used to test the horizontal and vertical vibrations of the left disk and Channel-3 to test the vertical vibration of the right disk. The key phase and the rotating speed are both measured and calculated by the same eddy current sensor, and the sampling frequency is adjusted automatically according to the rotating speed. The data acquisition hardware used is the National Instrument USB-4432 Module and software SKVMA Rotating Machinery Monitoring System.

sec.title: Experimental results and analysis
sec.p: The vibration response was collected while the speed was rising smoothly from 130 to 1740 r/min within about 5 min. The horizontal (Channel-1) and vertical (Channel-2) vibrations of the left disk and the vertical vibration (Channel-3) of the right disk were recorded for analysis. The testing data show that the vibration amplitude increases quickly when the rotating speed exceeds 1300 r/min, and so the system was shut down for safety at about 1740 r/min when the vibration amplitude reached about 180 µm. Examinations were carried out and the main shaft was found to be misaligned with the output shaft of the gearbox.

Figure 10 shows the waveforms in the four rotation periods of the horizontal vibration of the left disk at 300, 900, 1500 and 1732 r/min, respectively. It can be observed that there are some minor peaks between the four periods of the major waveforms, which means that there are multiple frequency vibrations. Figure 10.
Waveforms of the horizonal vibrations of the left disk.

The spectrum of the horizonal vibration of the left disk while starting up is shown in Figure 11. The annotation on the spectrum diagram shows the first five major peak values (Y-coordinates) and the corresponding frequencies (X-coordinates) which are sorted in descending order according to the values of the vibration power. In the spectrum diagrams, the response includes 1X, 2X, 3X, 4X, 5X, and other multiple frequency components. It is obvious that the magnitude of 2X component is much higher than that of 1X one, except the response at 1732 r/min, which indicates that the vibration caused by misalignment is stronger than the vibration caused by unbalance. Figure 11.
Spectra of the horizonal vibrations of the left disk.

For an unbalanced Jeffcott rotor, it is well known that the orbit is elliptical if the vibration of the rotor only conatins one frequency component. Since the vibration of the testrig rotor contains not only the rotating frequency (1X) vibration, but also some servere multiple frequency components (2X,3X, and 4X), the orbits will have superposition of the vibrations of different frequencies, as shown in Figure 12. The main profile of the orbit is of the shape ‘8’, which is known caused by the superposition of 1X and 2X harmonic vibrations. Figure 12.
Center orbits of the left disk.

Figure 13 shows the modified Bode plot of the horizontal vibration of the left disk. The fast Fourier transform is carried out for the responses at different speeds during starting up, and the amplitude–frequency and phase–frequency maps of the 1X and 2X components of the rotating frequency are both plotted in the figure. The modified Bode plot can clearly trend the amplitude variation of different frequency components. When the speed is lower than 1650 r/min, the amplitude of the 2X component is much higher than that of 1X one, as shown in the amplitude–speed diagram of the Bode plot. However, as the speed raises, yet still smaller than the first critical speed of the rotor system, the amplitude of 1X vibration, which was mainly caused by unbalance, increases quickly and becomes larger than that of 2X vibration. Figure 13.
Modified Bode plot of the horizontal response of the left disk.

These can also be observed from the spectrum diagrams in Figures 14 and 15. There are 1X, 2X, 3X, 4X, 5X, and 6X harmonic components in the vibration response, among which 1X and 2X components are the major ones. The 2X harmonic vibration is dominant when the rotating speed is lower than 1650 r/min, but 1X vibration is dominant when the speed is higher than 1650 r/min. Figure 14.
Spectra cascade of horizontal responses of the left disk (Channel-1).
Figure 15.
Spectra waterfall of horizontal responses of the left disk (Channel-1).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p:
In this study, the influence of coupling misalignment on the dynamic characteristics of an unbalanced multi-disk rotor supported by oil lubricated journal bearings are investigated experimentally and theoretically. The governing equations considering the nonlinear oil film force are derived based on the lumped mass model of the rotor. The forces and moments caused by coupling misalignment are the functions of the misaligning amount, and are treated as external excitations to the rotor system. The unbalanced responses of the system with and without misalignment are calculated using a numerical integration method and comparisons made between those two conditions. Time domain waveforms, orbits, and spectrum are used to analyze the dynamic characteristics of the responses with/without coupling misalignment. The experimental study matches well with the theoretical study. The following conclusions can be obtained through this study.
Misalignment can cause multiple frequency vibrations, including 2X, 3X, 4X, 5X, and other multiple frequency components of vibration, among which the 2X vibration is dominant.
Misalignment does not change the first critical speed of the rotor system, but may delay the occurrence and decrease the vibration amplitude of oil whip due to the constraint of the coupling.
The influence of the misalignment on a rotor system decreases as the distance between the concerned node with the misaligned coupling increases.
The model of the reacting forces and moments caused by the misalignment used in this study is clear and easy to use, which is effective for the qualitative analysis.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The study is supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China [NSFC No. 10732060] and the Research Fund of State Key Lab of Mechanical System and Vibration of China, Shanghai Jiao Tong University [Grant No. MSV-MS-2010-9].
